title: 112_hr770
content: The Act titled "Border Enforcement Security Task Force Act of 2011" is declared for the purpose of enhancing border security. Congress finds that the Department of Homeland Security's mission is to protect the United States, with ICE enforcing laws related to border security and criminal smuggling. The surge in border crime and violence on Mexico's northern border is attributed to competition between drug cartels and smuggling organizations, posing challenges for law enforcement agencies at the US northern border. The Department of Homeland Security partners with various law enforcement agencies to address border security threats through the Border Enforcement Security Task Force (BEST) initiative. BEST teams include personnel from ICE, CBP, DEA, ATFE, FBI, USCG, and USAO to enhance collaboration and information-sharing. The USAO collaborates with Federal, State, and local law enforcement agencies, as well as foreign agencies like Mexico's SSP, Canada's CBSA, OPP, and RCMP. SEC. 3. BORDER ENFORCEMENT SECURITY TASK FORCE. Established in United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), the Border Enforcement Security Task Force (BEST) program aims to enhance border security by collaborating with various law enforcement agencies to address and reduce security threats and violence. BEST units consist of personnel from ICE. The Border Enforcement Security Task Force (BEST) program, led by United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), collaborates with various law enforcement agencies to enhance border security. BEST units include personnel from ICE, United States Customs and Border Protection, the United States Coast Guard, other Federal agencies, State law enforcement agencies, foreign law enforcement agencies, local law enforcement agencies from affected border cities and communities, and tribal law enforcement agencies. The Secretary of Homeland Security, through the Assistant Secretary for ICE, is authorized to establish BEST units in jurisdictions where they can contribute to the program's missions. The Assistant Secretary considers factors like cross-border threats, law enforcement resources, and impact on border security when establishing a BEST unit. The Secretary of Homeland Security can provide federal assistance by allocating funds for the program. The Secretary of Homeland Security can allocate funds for the BEST program, assign federal personnel, and assist jurisdictions to participate. A report on the program's effectiveness in enhancing border security and reducing crime must be submitted to Congress annually. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to allocate funds for the BEST program to investigate and prosecute drug trafficking, arms smuggling, and other crimes along the international borders of the United States.
